profileText: A Representative from Kentucky; born in Mercer County, Ky., June 22, 1800; attended the public schools; engaged in mercantile pursuits from 1817 to 1821; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1823 and commenced practice in Harrodsburg, Ky.; prosecuting attorney 1829-1844; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-fourth Congress and reelected as a Whig to the Twenty-fifth Congress (March 4, 1835-March 3, 1839); secretary of state of Kentucky 1840-1844; member of the State house of representatives in 1845; attorney general of Kentucky from 1850 until his death in Frankfort, Franklin County, Ky., February 18, 1863.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Harlan, James. Remarks of Mr. Harlan, of Kentucky, on the Mississippi contested election. Washington: Printed by Gales and Seaton, 1837.

researchRecord.name: ca. 15 items.
researchRecord.description: Personal, business, and congressional papers and correspondence, chiefly in the James Harlan miscellaneous papers. Several letters scattered in other collections, especially the John B. Bruner papers and the Hickman collection. Autobiographical or biographical sketch in the Charles Lanman collection. Finding aid in repository. Restricted.

researchRecord.name: In John Marshall Harlan papers, 1810-1971, 21.2 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Includes financial and legal papers relating in part to his election to the House of Representatives and Kentucky and national politics. Unpublished finding aid in repository.
